discussion.content:
I don't think it can be B, it says that the bookmark of the website redirects the user to the new website which means it has the correct name.

I think it's most likely C.

comments.content: No problem, we're all in this together!

The name of the bookmark or bank doesn't matter, what's stored in the bookmark is an IP Address that takes you to the new site, no problem there. The issue is the old certificate with the wrong name creating a trust issue and not loading the website. The answer is B.

questions.question_text: The website of a bank that an organization does business with is being reported as untrusted by the organization's web browser. A security analyst has been assigned to investigate. The analyst discovers the bank recently merged with another local bank and combined names. Additionally, the user's bookmark automatically redirects to the website of the newly named bank. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of the issue?

choices.C: The website was created too recently to be trusted
choices.A: The company's web browser is not up to date
choices.B: The website's certificate still has the old bank's name

discussion.content: Lessons Learned seems correct. They have already Identifed problem, Eradicated problem (imaged and copied to hardened server) and Recovered (previous connection re-established). That just leaves Lessons Learned.
shouldn't this be containment? They just identified the issue

comments.content: "copied onto a hardened VM, with the previous connections re-established" = recovery
Correct. They are in the recovery phase. So next step is Lesson learned
If you read carefully they have the server up and running which is the Recovery phase and after that comes Lessons Learned.
Bob33 provides a lot of bad answers.

questions.question_text: A company recently experienced a security breach. The security staff determined that the intrusion was due to an out-of-date proprietary software program running on a non-compliant server. The server was imaged and copied onto a hardened VM, with the previous connections re-established. Which of the following is the NEXT step in the incident response process?

choices.A: Enable proper error handling on the web server
choices.D: Disable directory enumeration in the scanning policy
choices.B: Run scans during off peak hours

discussion.content: I think answer should be B as A has nothing to do in this case. Latency occurred due to the scanning performed .
The answer is correct as 4xx errors are client side errors which can be fixed with proper error handling.
I think is B, for the context of the question

Given answer may be correct - given error code 404 at end of log entry. 
404 error indicates that the webpage you're trying to reach can't be found. You might see a 404 error because of a problem with the website, because the page was moved or deleted, or because you typed the URL wrong. The simplest and easiest way to fix your 404 error code is to redirect the page to another one. You can perform this task using a 301 redirect. What's 301, you may ask? It's a redirect response code that signals a browser that the content has been transferred to another URL.

Could someone tell why B is incorrect? I thought the question states it's a highly utilized e-commerce server, so if the scanning is done during off-peak hours, it might not result in eventual service unavailability. 

Also, could someone please tell me what's the proper way to handle 404 - Not Found?

Thanks

Fuzzing is a means of testing that an application's input validation routines work well. Fuzzing means that the test or vulnerability scanner generates large amounts of deliberately invalid and/or random input and records the responses made by the application. This is a form of "stress testing" that can reveal how robust the application is.

questions.question_text: A developer has just finished coding a custom web application and would like to test it for bugs by automatically injecting mailformed data into it. Which of the following is the developer looking to perform?

discussion.content: During Risk assessment so it's B

comments.content: Because the question asks for the BEST example. Website defacement is the most straightforward way to impact the reputation

choices.D: Malware collecting credentials for company bank accounts
choices.B: A misconfigured firewall exposing intellectual property to the Internet
choices.C: An attacker defacing the e-commerce portal
choices.A: A bad software patch taking down the production systems

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST example of a reputation impact identified during a risk assessment?
